reviewText:
Timeless and nostalgic // Recommended for those who grew up in the nineties, who 'remember the days'
+ Auto-aim works consistently (though it has some issues with enemies at higher/lower elevations that must be compensated for)
+ Level design is mostly excellent; encourages exploration and isn't needlessly restrictive
+ Voiceovers are excellent for the year of release, particularly that of Darth Vader (I'm fairly certain it's the original voice actor from the films)
+ Story is nothing spectacular, but it works well as a Star Wars game and stays fiercely loyal to the spirit of the franchise
+ Great variety of weapons, some of them refreshingly original
+ Audio design (weapon & enemy, etc.) is taken directly from the films
+ In stark contrast to the expectedly lackluster detail in the walls and floor, the character and enemy sprites are as detailed as can be possible given the limitations of the day
+ Switch and level puzzles are a great throwback to simpler mechanics from a simpler age; they are (mostly) not particularly frustrating, and most levels flow competently as a result

- Uses DOS Box; cannot use Steam overlay, and minimization of the client tends to alter the Windows color scheme
- Controller support is virtually nonexistant
- The antagonist has no character depth or development
- Despite generally excellent level design, there are exceptions that stand out as being quite frustrating to navigate and proceed through (eg. Sewers)

reviewText:
Star Wars: Dark Forces was one of the first video game entries to incorporate elements of the expanded universe. Built on an enhanced version of the DOOM engine, Dark Forces reset the bar for first person shooters. It introduces the lasting character of Kyle Katarn into the universe and proved that you don't have to be a Jedi or a starfighter pilot to make a successful Star Wars game. An epic storyline, combined with memorable characters and impressive level design makes this game a must have for any Star Wars fan, or those looking for a sense of nostalga about how far gaming has come.

The graphics were top notch at the time of release (1995) with smooth animation and distinct sprites and textures. Digital voice work is crisp and helps to give the characters a sense of personality. From the filtered 'halt!' of stormtroopers to the anamalistic groan of the Diagnosa as you wade through raw sewage, you will always know exactly what is hunting you.

Gameplay is standard fare for shooters of the time. you have a wide variety of weapons - pistols, blaster rifles, thermal detonators, along with more exotic weapons such as the fusion cutter or the assault plasma cannon. Health is non-regenerating and must be restored from medkits, along with shields.

Sound direction is excellent. The music features remixes of well known Star Wars tunes along with new music. Each tune fits the level it is attached to. Weapon sounds are unique, giving every gun its own feel.

Overall, this is a geat game for retro lovers. Solid gameplay, a memorable story that has influenced many other games in the franchise, and characters with actual personality makes this a good choice.

On the technical side, this game comes bundled with its own auto-loading version of DOSBox, meaning that it will work on modern systems. Confirmed functional on all systems up to Windows 7 64-bit, with reports of it working properly on Windows 8 systems.

9/10.

reviewText:
Many call this game just a Doom clone, but of course it's not as simple as that. Like most games from the early days of the (partial) 3D first-person shooter genre, Dark Forces builds on what was established by its predecessors. It takes Doom's formula, uses it as the foundations and creates something new and improved (just like Doom did with Wolfenstein 3D). From a gameplay perspective it is quite similar, but a number of key features have been added which were quite new in 1995.

In addition to all the typical stuff you'd expect from a mid-1990s shooter, Dark Forces also allows the player to aim vertically (this can however only be done using the numpad; the mouse is used for horizontal aiming instead). Other features added by the Jedi engine are the ability to jump and crouch and a number of atmospheric effects. Some missions require the use of a headlamp, night vision, gas mask, special boots and other tools. The player can also throw thermal detonators (explosives).

Dark Forces is set in the Star Wars universe. Since it is a licensed production, everything from the visuals and sound effects have a distinct feel. If you enjoyed the original trilogy of Star Wars (episodes IV, V and VI), this game will certainly make you feel nostalgic. The levels are slightly less abstract than Doom, but they are still very well designed and quite complicated, also forcing the player to think by adding various puzzles throughout. Dark Forces has a total of 14 missions and during the course of the game you will see aesthetically different environments.

Besides differences in gameplay and visuals, Dark Forces is also more story-focused than the Doom games. You play as Kyle Katarn, a mercenary recruited by the Rebel Alliance, one that used to work for the Galactic Empire. The plot begins shortly before the events of Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope, but gradually takes you past the ending of the film and takes place between A New Hope and Star Wars Episode V: The Empire Strikes Back. It's not masterful storytelling, but the simple plot and visually pleasant cutscenes make the game more engaging.

Overall, the game's numerous mechanical improvements and technological advancements make it a natural successor to Doom 2, adding variety to the Doom gameplay formula. Star Wars: Dark Forces was a brilliant game for its time; since then it has influenced other amazing titles (such as Duke Nukem 3D) and remains a classic.

NOTE: The Steam re-release of this game isn't entirely up to scratch. Upon launching the game, you will experience terrible performance issues (especially when there are multiple enemies on screen). It's nothing that a quick Google search can't fix, but it should be in-game from the get-go.

Definitely a blast from *my* past; when I was a kid I played the first level over and over again. Never got past it until now, when I can proudly say I've beaten the game (on Easy, but nonetheless the game has been beaten). It was pretty fun, too.
The music's been well remixed in bleeps and bloops, and reacts dynamically to the situation. I played with the game in a window, which I think works better than full-screen - the assets are pretty pixelly, especially for objects far in the distance. Apparently I fought Boba Fett at one point, but I didn't know - he was flying around and I was just trying not to get shot too many times, so I couldn't tell it was him.
I like how there's no objective marker (though a mini-map would come in handy, and a nicer one than the one that appears if you hit tab or F1) and the levels are kind of maze-like, and yet no matter how lost I am, I always blunder to the objective somehow. reviewText:
Star Wars Dark Forces is a FPS set during the events of the original Star Wars movie trilogy. In a nice surprise you don't follow the events of the movies but instead work as a mercenary for the Rebels. You are a mercenary called Kyle Katarn who is fully voice acted and seems to be in it for more than the money. In your travels you will discover that the Empire is working on a secret project to make Dark Troopers and it becomes your main reason for most of the missions. Along your travels you will encounter some familiar characters. Most will only appear in cutscenes and don't show up in game so don't go in expecting to be able to gun down Darth Vader.

Your journeys will take you to a wide variety of environments and nearly each one feels unique and introduce more and more enemies. Most levels are enormous and they will take you quite some time to beat. It's not just running and gunning though, there will be rather difficult puzzles and actual objectives like rescuing a hostage or stealing data and making a run for the spacecraft. It's a nice change from most FPS games of the time where your only goal is to reach the end of the level. As unique and varied as the levels are the actual level design can be very confusing at times. A considerable portion of my playtime comes from being at an utter loss of where I am supposed to head to next and it definitely impacts the game negatively.

Strangely Dark Forces does not allow you to save manually and the game will only save after you complete a level. You start off with three lives and can find more throughout the level though they are usually well hidden. If you see cracks on a wall it is likely you can blow it up and find some goodies. And my biggest gripe with this game is the amount of platforming you will be required to do. The controls do not feel tight enough for platforming and with the lack of quick saving it can truly be irradiating. Luckily the gun-play is top notch and there are a wide variety of weapons to dispose of your enemies. Some do share ammo like the pistol and the blaster which adds more strategy since you will have to decide if the situation is dangerous enough to use more ammo with the blaster. You can also punch out Stormtroopers or other enemies, which is very amusing to me but should be used as a last resort.

It is very true to it's source material having each gun sound exactly like in the movies, Stormtroopers shouting “Rebel scum!” and most of the music in Dark Forces are from the film but remade into MIDI format. I'm not sure if all the weapons are canon but this game does not feature lightsabers in case you were wondering. The story itself is mediocre and mostly told through cutscenes after or before missions. Most of the voice acting is surprisingly good especially Darth Vader and your character not being a generic mute protagonist is also appreciated. There is a nice sense of urgency as your enemies get more and more powerful as you progress through the story and you will definitely find out why the Rebels are so worried about the Empire's secret project. If you are having difficulty seeing remember that you have have night vision goggles which use up energy that you obtain by blowing up cleaning droids.

This version of the game has modern controls right out the box. You will be moving around with “wasd” and aiming with the mouse. Strangely you will not be able to look up and down using the mouse. There is no way to see the control scheme or rebind in game which is kind of annoying. Combat is fast paced and enjoyable. Most enemies have different means of attack like either shooting you or running toward you for a melee attack and it is very easy to tell an enemy apart allowing you to adapt and respond to a situation on the fly. A certain enemy in the sewer level stalks you from the sludge and boy, did they creep me out. When you pick up a powerup that doubles your rate of fire the game usually throws a large amount of enemies at you which is always a blast as you mow down all in your path and after all is said and done you will feel like the best darn mercenary money can buy.

Overall Dark Forces is a pretty fun game kept from greatness due to a few serious design decisions. The flaws of having confusing level design, no saving, and controls not suited for the sometimes fatal platforming is just too deadly a combination. It is still a good game don't get me wrong. I had a blast playing through it and seeing Stormtroopers being competent fighters for once.  It is also pretty advanced for it's time featuring voiced cutscenes, level objectives and  an actual story to back it up. It is not a must play for those of us that are not a fan of the films but it's still a decent old school shooter. Though if you like both the FPS genre and Star Wars you should definitely check out this title.

reviewText:
Like any game this old, any recommendation is going to come with a lot of salt, and largely boils down to your personal tolerance level.

Dark Forces is basically Doom with a Star Wars wallpaper, though apparently it made a few technological improvements over Doom, such as the ability to have multiple floors on top of one another. This is just heresay on my part, I'm not a videogame historian.

The level design is fairly nonlinear and encourages plenty of exploration, but personally I found that the inability to look up and down (more than about 45 degrees either way, with really weird visual distortions) left me having only a vague idea that a floor was beneath my feet, which was incredibly disorienting and left me playing through most of the game with the transparent map screen plastered to my face (though I'll admit I found the way the map dynamically updated based on purely literal line of sight weirdly enthralling).

Like many FPSes, or indeed games of this age in general, the bosses ammount to little more than a single enemy that is both better at killing you and worse at dying. Can't really dock points there, it's not like you can expect elaborate boss mechanics in a game that slightly predates the notion of having to actually aim your gun at things.

While I still had enough fun to give this game a recommendation, do NOT try playing it without a walkthrough on hand. Many of the puzzles involve a sort of sideways moon logic that I never would have figured out on my own, even if I could fnavigate without staring at the map during firefights.

reviewText:
LucasArts (rip in piece) took a step into first person action games with 1995's Dark Forces.

One thing that makes this Doom clone stand out is a lot of engine work. There are various differences in geometry, such as cliffs, pits, platforms, etc, and ambient lighting is colored, as well as colored fog.

Gameplay wise, you play as mercenary Kyle Katarn as he under takes missions for the Rebellion. From stealing the Death Star plans to escaping Jabba the Hutt's sail barge, the game throws you into maps, and gives you goals.

Unlike Doom, you don't just find the exit. You actually have objectives to do, and if you fail those objectives, you lose the level.

The voice acting is quite good for the time, the gameplay and maps are all great, and the game proved that LucasArts could craft amazing story lines with it's own universe. The Dark Forces series remains one of the best Star Wars series availible, and I would recommend this game to pretty much anyone that likes Star Wars.

reviewText:
One of the very first games I played as a child back in the 90's, Star Wars Dark Forces is without a doubt, one of the best Star Wars games I have ever played. This game is similar to Doom 2, where the levels are fairly linear, finding keys to locked doors is a necessity, and there are several mini bosses that you will encounter. I personally am not too much of a graphics freak so the pixels do not bother me, but that should not turn anyone away from this gem of a game. I bought this game during one of the sales (Summer/Autumn/Winter) at around $2. While the replay value is very low as there are a set number of missions with no achievements or multiple endings, you will get your $2 back and more. Pass on the coffee or candy bar and do not miss the rare chance to be able to punch a Kell Dragon in the face.

*The game requires DosBox however, with the Steam download, everything will be set up for you to enjoy as soon as the game is downloaded.

Story/Characters:

You follow Kyle Katarn before his Jedi days as a Rebel mercenary. In my opinion, the story is a tad on the darker side when it comes to Star Wars. The basic premise is that you are the hero as you try to defeat the Empire with their new Dark Trooper project.

Gameplay:

The gameplay is very straightforward as you clear levels by going to the end/objective. There are no Force powers, lightsabers, or Jedi. Point and shoot at baddies shooting back at you. Thankfully, there are no escort missions.

Graphics:

The game is from the 90's.

Sound/Music:

Enemies will grunt and scream/squeal as they are shot/blown apart/punched to death. Music is always superb from John Williams, although after a while, the music for the missions will continue to loop.

Controls:

By today's standards, in my opinion, the controls are not so good. You will have to use the arrow keys to move and with the mouse, you can only look left or right. To look up or down, you are forced to use the Home and End keys. There is a fix for this however, in the form of a file called Glovepie" which allows you to use your mouse to look in all directions.

Replay value:

There is little to no replay value as there are no achievements. I suppose if you want to run through the game by changing the difficulty levels (Easy

Hard) you could play three times or start a playthrough with only fists.

None.

reviewText:
Dark Forces is a great oldschool FPS if you know you like those sorts of games. It's really fun pew-pewing half the stormtroopers in the Empire, at least.

Like most of its contempraries, this game was groundbreaking; in DF's case it gave people in the mid-1990s the feeling of being in a Star Wars movie (that wasn't a prequel: those would come out a couple years later). Unlike most of its contemporaries, it accomplished this partly by putting actual effort into telling a story. Nothing amazing, but it's good enough to keep you playing and find out what that rascally Darth Vader is up to next.

The DosBOX port is actually good as long as you edit the configuration file to double the allotted CPU cycles - it runs like a turtle uphill otherwise. There's a checkpoint system to make up for the lack of saving in the levels, which can get rather labyrinthine, so keep that in mind. The game still isn't quite as hard or long as the old DOOM could get, especially since Kyle Katarn here punches like a literal champ.

As an aside, this was the only Dark Forces game I was interested in, due to its similarity to the old Doom formula (the engine is very similar to Duke Nukem 3D's Build) and because I'm not that interested in being a magical overpowered Jedi.

reviewText:
For starters I will be playing this via DOSBox.  Because unless you have an old Compaq Presario 5528 with Windows 95 on it sitting in the closet, you will too.  Which means, that since DOSBox is pretty much a requirment to play the game, I’ll be including it in the aspects of the review.

As I have said before, and I’m sure, will say many times again.  I wont ever down an old game for its graphics.  If the game had bad or poor graphics, in relation to competition at the time of it’s release, I might.  But so long as things are at least par for its time, I wont argue it.



DOS Box is a neat little program that allows older DOS programs to run in the Windows environment.  It’s noting too fancy in that regard, but it does allow for a complete control customizing, something Dark Forces would otherwise be without.

Dark Forces graphics are great for its time, and a strain for the eyes now.  This is one of those games that I don’t expect a lot of people to go run out and play.  If you’ve been playing Battlefront II all weekend and then try to play Dark Forces.  Well, its gonna suck, plain and simple.  Especially if you’ve never played it before.  But again, this isn’t me saying this is a bad game, just uncontrollably dated graphics.

The story is excellent, giving the means to tell it.  There is the backstory, that unfortunately is not with the Steam version since it was in the original game manual.  But with a quick Google search can be found easily.  The meat of the story is told in short cutscenes and the mission briefings.  With the occasional comments from Kyle Katarn as you play.

I would absolutely love to see someone remake this game.  Using a modern engine, or ever just a less dated one.  Yea, it was tried, but that project was recently canceled.  It does strike me as odd though.  With Dark Forces being a landmark game.  For all gamers, not just the Star Wars nerds.  It seems like someone should have done this, and done it fully some time ago.  This is what people want.  If it could have been done with Doom, it can be done with Dark Forces!

The level design is better than I expected.  It doesn’t follow that flat maze and corridor style I was expecting it to have.  Perhaps I’m thinking too much about Wolfenstein 3D?  There are places that could use improvement, but then when isn’t there?  And they make great use of the multiple floors, remember that was a big deal when this game came out.  So of course, there are stairs everywhere.

Dark Forces is one of those games where you can take your time and take in the sites or just run for it.  Either way you play it you get pretty much the same experience.  A sit down with it, will show what gaming was like ten plus years ago.  You wont be blown away by anything by any means, but you might gain a little more admiration for the old school.

An excellent game for what it is, but unfortunately, doesn't hold up well to modern standards.  Which to be honest was completely expected.

http://bosniannerd.blogspot.com/2015/02/star-wars-dark-forces.html

Dark Forces. If you were playing games back in 1995 you most definitely know about this first person shooter and you are probably wondering why I am writing about it in 2015? Honestly, the game was included in a recent game bundle and I decided to check out how well did it age. You know, some games may be awesome at the time they were released, but as the time passes and games evolve, some of those old favorites end up being very bad. And we wonder how come we loved them so much back then and now they seem like games we'd never play for more than 15 minutes. Anyway, before I move on I want you to know that I didn't really like this game even when it was first released. Just as I didn't like Doom, a game that Dark Forces was too often compared to. I didn't dislike it either, I just thought it was an average Star Wars game and an average FPS and it was well accepted just because it was set in Star Wars universe.

So, how well did it age? Not good. First of all, you need a DOS emulator (DOSBox) to run it on a modern computer, but if you are using a Steam version of Dark Forces you don't have to worry about it as Steam was nice enough to set up DOSBox for you. The resolution is extremely low (640x400) and everything is very pixelated. There's another solution for this (and more) called DarkXL. DarkXL allows you to play Dark Forces even in full HD (1920x1080) resolution and/or in a window (as I prefer it). It doesn't just stretch the pixels as you may have thought, it really has new game textures and makes everything look a lot nicer. Don't expect wonders though, the graphics are still more or less the same, it just looks a lot more polished.

By default, you use mouse only to look left and right and if you want to look up and down, and more importantly shoot enemies who are above or below you, you need to use PageUp and PageDown buttons on the keyboard. Actually, the game will usually shoot up and down automatically if you line up the reticle with the enemy, but it's extremely frustrating and unforgiving at times. DarkXL fixes this as well as it allows you to use fully use mouse and view your surroundings. Trust me, this helps a LOT and not only with shooting the imperial scum, but also with switches and doors.

However, DarkXL is incomplete and will probably remain so. There are certain bugs that have been reported and the most important are present in the very last level. You will be unable to complete the game with these bugs (you will have to cheat to advance and to give you a hint: hold G to move through walls) and it's a real shame. Especially since regular save game file is incompatible with DarkXL save game file, meaning you cannot just switch back to normal game and complete what's left regularly. Another annoying bug (or a missing feature?) is lack of weapons. If you play through the game using DarkXL you will be unable to pick up the strongest 2-3 weapons for a reason unknown to me. You can use another cheat to unlock and equip those weapons though, so it's a minor issue at the end.

Now that you know how you can enjoy the game better using DarkXL, lets get back to the game itself. The story is mostly unimportant: you are Kyle Katarn, a mercenary who works for Rebel Alliance. You are being sent on a series of missions to find out about the latest Imperial project and ultimately destroy it. An army of Storm troopers, Imperial commanders and commandos, droids and other aliens will stand in your way as you progress through 14 levels consisting of mining facilities, space stations, cities and other environments. The levels are average in size, have no respawning enemies and will take an average of 30 minutes to complete (more if you play on hard since you have to be more careful). Most levels will require you to find switches, cards or buttons to open up certain doors in order to advance. However, I hated that part a lot. Why? Simply because you will often run into a switch or a lever, use it and... wonder what actually happened? The levels are not linear and you can wander around as much as you want, and as good as that is it confuses you because you are not sure what did that switch do. There is no objective pointer" to tell you where to go (this is a 1995 game after all) and it's especially frustrating in missions where you have to go back to your ship after you complete the mission. I walked around for more than 20 minutes on one mission

reviewText:
It's been a long time since I've played this one. This is actually the first time I've completed it.

The coolest thing about Dark Forces is its atmosphere. It's genuine Star Wars, more than almost any other Star Wars related game I've seen. Everything is done right here - from interiors (all those shafts, white corridors, control panels - just like in the movies) to the sounds of doors opening. It's funny how subsequent Star Wars games couldn't make this as authentic, despite having all kinds of technological advantages.

Gameplay is very simple but still satisfying as hell. First few missions are little boring but then it gets better and better. My personal favorite is the one on Nar Shaddaa. The final mission was awesome too - very challenging and intense.

The graphics here are basically huge flickering pixels all over the screen. I've never had any serious issues with dated visuals but still I got to get used to these graphics for some time (it's been a while since I've played something that old). Even had a minor headache for the first 30-40 minutes - you got to strain your eyes sometimes because at first you can't even tell what's ahead of you in pixels. But once you get used to it, it feels totally fine. I must say, I still like this look better than early polygonal games which look unspeakably ugly.

The plot here is also really simple, but at least it's not something like Battle of Hoth or Death Star assault for the 100th time, it's its own thing. Yeah, back in pre-Disney Star Wars era we used to think it was Kyle Katarn, not the chick from The Theory of Everything, who stole the plans of Death Star and handed them to Leia.
I liked all that Dark Trooper Project thing. It's nothing that great, but it fits the universe and works fine for a little spin-off story.

Definitely try this if you're into Star Wars (and Doom) and not scared of 1995 graphics and archaic controls. Still entertaining.

I remember playing this game back on the PS1. The main character is a badass who works as a Merc for the Rebellion. Due to this flexibility, he isn't a main part of the alliance, but he certainly perfers it then working for the empire.

The story to this game is you play as this character during the events of Star Wars Episode IV, and V I believe, it has been a while since I completed this game. The first mission involves you doing something none of the other Rebel Infiltraitor's had done, retrieve the blueprints to the death star. As any Star Wars fan knows, the plans are what revealed a weak point in the Death Star's defences and the leader even mentioned how they lost many men attempting to get that information.

You are then called in because a Rebel base when silent from an attack, but this was no ordinary attack as the entire base was taken out and if it was a army, they would've seen it coming and evacuated or atleast shot many of them down before going into hiding. It's then revealed that one of the most interesting enemies of the Star Wars franchile is created here. The Dark Troopers. Commando Troopers that are far more powerful and destructive than you're average trooper as they can take out entire complexs by themselves.

Many weapons you get are references to the ones from the film such as blaster pistol, blaster rifle, Thermal Detonator and quite a few interesting and creative weapon designs.

It's well worth a play if you can get a hang of the controls and remember how Lucas Arts used to make years ago as this was during the age they made adventure games and before they went lax and started making half-♥♥♥♥♥ games.

reviewText: I felt kind of odd recommending every single game I own and finish here, so before you take this review as a big strong NO, accept it in the context of my library – if there is one game in my library I would not recommend thus far, it would be this one. It’s not because of technical issues or my hate of the game, I actually quite like it, but since I played it before, I’ve decided to play it on hard this time around and it revealed a couple of issues this game gained by aging very, very poorly. First off, the controls. The look up and down buttons are mapped somewhere to the numpad and thus every instance of looking up or down turns into an ordeal. It’s especially annoying when an enemy surprises you by standing on a heightened platform or straight under you, because you learn about it the painful way and before you can react accordingly by adjusting the view, your shield is dropping like vases in cartoons. There’s no in-game ability to remap the keys either. What’s more surprising – no mid-level saves, so screw up right before the end and prepare to rage quit. Now before you think of me as some amateur noob, let me assure you that that’s a thing that crossed my mind as well. But there’s challenging and then there’s straight broken ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. So if there is a turret placed on the ceiling of a maintenance tunnel/ventilation duct, doesn’t make a warning sound and is able to blast your bum from here to Tatooine with spotless accuracy, that’s just bad game design. When a mine blows my jacket straight off, because the only warning of its position behind a crate is a short beeping sound signaling that I just entered a domain of pain, I would enjoy at least a single checkpoint. This game is not a Doom clone, despite looking like one. It’s packed with ambitious innovation, which is alas very poorly implemented. And if you turn the difficulty up in Doom, that game at least has the decency to lift you off the tracks after shoving you under a train. This game, on the other hand, will shoot your kneecaps as soon as you scramble back onto your feet. And if you don’t plan on playing this game on hard, or conversely at least don’t mind putting your face to a cheese grater, then you may just enjoy this old fossil.

reviewText:
Before i write this review  i wanted to say i wasn't sure if i should give it a positive or negative review. Obviously, by today's standards, this is a terrible game. But you also have to take into consideration that it was made in 1995. So it certinly wasn't going to be great. So, I'm going to write about some of the good and bad things about this game, I only gave it a negative review because i enjoyed many games made in the 90's. This game, however, is not one of them.
The only reason I bought this game was because of how much I loved Dark Forces II, So i figured I would enjoy this game just as much. But they're both completely different games.
First off: You will get lost VERY easily. There's never any clear indication as to where you're supposed to go. You do have a map but that really doesn't help. So you'll spend the majority of each level wandering around and going a bunch of places that don't lead anywhere. The game is also pretty easy combat wise. You'll almost never die, (although, i did only play the game in medium difficuilty) All you'll do is see something move and just hold down the left mouse button until he dies in one or two shots. It;s also a bit confusing at first. When i had completed all my objectives it didn't take me to the next level. Confused, i just wandered around for awhile figuring i had to find an exit. After awhile, i got a message saying i had to pause the game and click next mission. This was more than likely my fault i'll admit. It probably sent me that message as soon as i finished all my objectives when i wasn't paying attention. But it's still odd and confusing.
It actually has a pretty good atmosphere. At one point it was even pretty creepy. During the second level you have to go down this water drain and you'll end up in this really dark room in waist high sewage water. After i walked around for awhile i heard a sort of growl. It actually creeped me out quite a bit. As i continued i heard more growls but i still couldn't see anything. Until, finally, i ran smack dab into this octopus looking creature that emerged from the water my immediate response was to hold down my fire button until it died. It was actually quite jarring.
All-In-All, It wasn't a horrible game, it's just not a game for most people. If you like games like DOOM then you'll probably enjoy this game. But, if you're just a fan of Star Wars or just saw this and it looked interesting. I would suggest not buying it.

reviewText:
Oh man, the memories! This was one of the first video games I ever played growing up in the mid to late nineties, and it has aged like fine cheese: pungent and stinky but delicious none the less. To those who actually remember the pre-sequel Star Wars era, this game does positiviely EVERYTHING right. The guns, the enemies, the locations, and of course the characters, are all done in a manner that is faithful to the Star Wars lore. When playing this game for the first time, everything feels new yet strangely familiar, which is EXACTLY how a Star Wars game should feel. You feel like you've heard the story before, but the manner in which it is being presented this time is unique and interesting. Atmospherically, this might just be one of the greatest examples of allowing level/character set the tone. Shiny Imperial starships feature well organized corridors patrolled by brisk, professional soldiers while filthy sewers are populated by dirty, grubby looking baddies with outfits that look like they've been cobbled together from trash and scrap.

Gameplay wise, the controls aren't as tight as they could be, only highlighting the fact that the platforming in this game is clunky at best. The story is no where near as long as it should be, and features only twelve missions. Despite its length, the story does do a good job of pulling you in and engaging you, even if it is a little corny even by Star Wars standards. The difficulty level is right about perfect, however. It is challenging without being impossible, yet simple enough that you rarely feel frustrated by it. That being said, the missions can feel a little bit confusing at times and you will occassionally feel like you don't know what you're supposed to do. Finally, the game's visuals haven't aged well and definately don't hold up to the standards that gamers expect out of a modern FPS. In all fairness, Datk Forces was on the cutting edge graphics-wise in 1995, and could look a lot worse. Its outdated graphical look adds a nostalgia factor to the game and give it an endearing quality that few retro indie games can match.

All in all, Star Wars: Dark Forces is most definately worth a play through. Whether you're a hardcore Star Wars fan or a gamer looking to play older games for the nostalgia factor, Dark Forces will scratch your itch and scratch it good. I would even recommend this game to any potential developers out there as a good lesson in atmospheric design. A true classic and an undeniable gem in Lucasart's crown.

This game comes highly recommended from tons of Star Wars nerds I've seen online. And... well, yeah, I enjoyed it as well. It definitely scores high on my Top Ten SW games I've played. It's a fun little Doom clone, where you play as a Rebel named Kyle Katarn as you steal the Death Star plans before the actual Star Wars film, and later uncover the secrets of a new Imperial army- The Dark Troopers. Of all the FPS' I've played, where you just fulfill missions, this game makes you feel like you're actually making progress. As you go on, you learn more about the Empire, their design of the Dark Troopers, who's in charge, where the Dark Troopers are made, what they're made of. You end up feeling like a real Rebel spy, in the end. And I like Jan Ors as a character. The story still makes sense in the greater scope of The Original Trilogy. One of the first things that surprised me was that it was an older game, Dark Forces came out in 1995 for MS-Dos. Which is why this game uses a pre-programed version of Dos-box to run the game on modern machines. I've played it on several computers, it seems to run just fine.

Dark Forces is the first in the Jedi Knight game series, you play as Kyle Katarn, a young mercenary, a cross between Han Solo and Luke Skywalker. In the future games Kyle grows to become a Jedi Knight, but in this game he's just a mercenary.

Gameplay is fine, think of a Star Wars meets Duke Nukem 3D. Dark Forces falls in from the time where 3D shooters weren’t quiet all 3D yet, a 2.5D pixel wonderland where you explore and take down stormtroopers and the evil dark stormtoopers.

Do you have a lightsaber? Nope. But you really don't need to, Dark Forces has you play as a one man army. You're not a Jedi. You're a hired gun, and honestly it's better this way. You're not this over powered superman with force powers, mowing down enemies. You're a dude turned against the empire. You're not in it to be noble, you're out for vengeance. This could have turned into an interesting series, you have this character go deeper and deeper to the darkside basically by killing stormtroopers for the wrong reasons, yet fighting for the right of the rebellion.

Instead, they dropped that, gave you a lightsaber, and called you a Jedi Knight in the sequel.

Dark Forces is an older game, don't expect to be wowed by the story or gameplay. You might be in for a shock to discover, much like myself that the Theme from Star Wars is played from a Midi version. But that's because its from that odd period of time. No, FMV... that’s for the sequel. If you're a Star Wars fan, you'll want to play this, and probably the rest of the Jedi Knight series.

Star Wars - Dark Forces is a First Person Shooter published by LucasArts in 1995 originally for MS-DOS and Apple Macintosh Computers. I originally got it when the Star Wars game bundle was on a massive sale on Steam. Out of the 10 games I purchased, I decided to try this one out first. Here are my first impressions of it.

Graphics - 9/10: The graphics in this game are very reminiscient of Doom and Wolfenstein, both being pioneers for the FPS genre created by ID Software. It is in a pseudo-3D first-person view with pixelated textures. I give it a high score for being very revolutionary for its time, however, that doesn't mean it is perfect. The main problem is clarity. In both Doom and Wolfenstein, the graphics were clear, and you could see all of the walls, text and enemies just fine. In this game, I find that a lot of the time it is hard to see the walls and openings. This game managed to bring out the most that DOS could supply, so I give it a high score.

Story - 9/10: From what I've gathered, the story of this gameis pretty much capturing data from the Death Star and bringing it back safely while fighting off Storm Troopers. This is exactly what you would expect from a Star Wars game, although I do take off a point for not much depth. The story is not particularly what you would care about, but it delivers exactly what you want for a Star Wars game.

Gameplay & Controls - 5/10: As you can see from my score, the gameplay does have some serious issues. First though, let me get out all of the positives out of the way. The gameplay does give you a good sense of exploration and does a solid of job when it comes to shooting. As for the controls, they do seem standard for the average FPS and can be adjustable easily. Now let's get to the negatives. A serious issue I had with the game play is that whenever you enter a room, you are completely vulnerable to enemy attack without being able to see where they are. There have been numerous times when I go up into an elevator, then as soon as I reach the top, I have to turn around to exit while my health bar is being drained by an enemy that I cannot shoot. The game also is very unexplanatory, as I could not easily figure out all of the controls without some explanation. The controls, when you figure them out however, can be a bit weird to use if you have been previously playing a 3D FPS. You're locked into a left-right point of view, so you can not look upwards or downwards. There are flaws with the gameplay and controls, but they aren't terrible. That's why they get a medium rating.

Summary: Overall, Star Wars - Dark Forces is not a perfect game, but still a good one. The gameplay could be better, but it is still a solid FPS and one of the better DOS games out there. For a price of only $5.99 without sales, I would consider it a good deal. I'm sure that there are better Star Wars games out there, but this one is still worth playing.

Star Wars - Dark Forces is a First Person Shooter published by LucasArts in 1995 originally for MS-DOS and Apple Macintosh Computers. I originally got it when the Star Wars game bundle was on a massive sale on Steam. Out of the 10 games I purchased, I decided to try this one out first. Here are my first impressions of it.

Graphics - 9/10: The graphics in this game are very reminiscient of Doom and Wolfenstein, both being pioneers for the FPS genre created by ID Software. It is in a pseudo-3D first-person view with pixelated textures. I give it a high score for being very revolutionary for its time, however, that doesn't mean it is perfect. The main problem is clarity. In both Doom and Wolfenstein, the graphics were clear, and you could see all of the walls, text and enemies just fine. In this game, I find that a lot of the time it is hard to see the walls and openings. This game managed to bring out the most that DOS could supply, so I give it a high score.

Story - 9/10: From what I've gathered, the story of this gameis pretty much capturing data from the Death Star and bringing it back safely while fighting off Storm Troopers. This is exactly what you would expect from a Star Wars game, although I do take off a point for not much depth. The story is not particularly what you would care about, but it delivers exactly what you want for a Star Wars game.

Gameplay & Controls - 5/10: As you can see from my score, the gameplay does have some serious issues. First though, let me get out all of the positives out of the way. The gameplay does give you a good sense of exploration and does a solid of job when it comes to shooting. As for the controls, they do seem standard for the average FPS and can be adjustable easily. Now let's get to the negatives. A serious issue I had with the game play is that whenever you enter a room, you are completely vulnerable to enemy attack without being able to see where they are. There have been numerous times when I go up into an elevator, then as soon as I reach the top, I have to turn around to exit while my health bar is being drained by an enemy that I cannot shoot. The game also is very unexplanatory, as I could not easily figure out all of the controls without some explanation. The controls, when you figure them out however, can be a bit weird to use if you have been previously playing a 3D FPS. You're locked into a left-right point of view, so you can not look upwards or downwards. There are flaws with the gameplay and controls, but they aren't terrible. That's why they get a medium rating.

Summary: Overall, Star Wars - Dark Forces is not a perfect game, but still a good one. The gameplay could be better, but it is still a solid FPS and one of the better DOS games out there. For a price of only $5.99 without sales, I would consider it a good deal. I'm sure that there are better Star Wars games out there, but this one is still worth playing.

It has all of the good traits that Doom Clones have, such as no cover, more than two weapon slots,  and non-linear maps.

The gunplay feels solid and gunning down enemies is satisfying.

The story is pretty good for a FPS released only a year and a few months after Doom II. It involves really good voice acting for the time period and some cut scenes that I imagine looked pretty good in 1995 but now have a certain retro charm to them.

The soundtrack really makes the most of it's MIDI music, and most of the songs still hold up today, especially the opening song. Unless you don't like MIDI music, in which case you probably won't like this game's music.

The environment is well designed, and does a good job capturing the feel of wherever the level is supposed to be set. This is an area  that I always thought that Doom I and II frequently fell short, so this is rather big deal.
